content.description: This is a tall problem featuring a technical crux down low and a mental crux up high. The technical crux requires figuring out how to get from the starting rail to a good crimp that’s up and left. It might be easier if you’re tall. This problem could be done from a stand start using the aforementioned crimp and a gaston at around V3ish.
content.protection: 2-3 crashpads, spotters optional. The topout is pretty high and several TV sized boulders occupy the LZ.
content.location: SDS on the left side of the face directly below the prominent ledge that’s about 15’ up. Match hands on the waist high right leaning rail to start, then climb up and a little left next to the corner on crimps and pockets. Once the ledge is gained move to the right several feet to avoid some loose rock guarding the topout.

content.description: This climbs the gently overhanging south face on crimps to a juggy topout.
content.location: SDS on a pair of crimps just to the right of 2 scrubby Hackberry trees. Make straight up moves on more crimps to reach the jugs above and top out.

content.description: This is the biggest freestanding boulder in the canyon. The west face at over 15 feet tall provides the longest problems. While the west face commands the attention, the slabby north face holds a couple of easy lines while the south face hosts dozens of juggy pockets. Due to its location its a good cold weather spot as it gets full sun from about midday on.
